paragraphs.text:
%md
# Query GS data
- Create a hive table (`wdi_gs`) against the gs wdi_2016 data.
- Count number of rows from the wdi_gs table

msg.data:
Query GS data

  • Create a hive table (wdi_gs) against the gs wdi_2016 data.
  • Count number of rows from the wdi_gs table

paragraphs.text:
-- NOTE semicolon is not allow in ezpplein
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS wdi_gs

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE wdi_gs
(year INTEGER, countryName STRING, countryCode STRING, indicatorName STRING, indicatorCode STRING, indicatorValue FLOAT)
ROW FORMAT DELIMITED FIELDS TERMINATED BY ',' LINES TERMINATED BY '\n'
LOCATION 'gs://jarvis_data_eng_james/datasets/wdi_2016'
TBLPROPERTIES ("skip.header.line.count"="1")

-- show table meta data
DESCRIBE FORMATTED wdi_gs

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Load GS Data to HDFS
The newly created Hive table (`wdi_csv_text`) is used to store data transfer from (`wdi_gs`) table. When we run the simple SELECT statement twnice, I noticed the run time difference. The secnod time is faster, because the file system cache holds data that was recently read from the disk.The data is obtain from cache rathar than having to read it again from the disk.

msg.data:
Load GS Data to HDFS

The newly created Hive table (wdi_csv_text) is used to store data transfer from (wdi_gs) table. When we run the simple SELECT statement twnice, I noticed the run time difference. The secnod time is faster, because the file system cache holds data that was recently read from the disk.The data is obtain from cache rathar than having to read it again from the disk.

paragraphs.text: DROP TABLE IF EXISTS wdi_csv_text

--Create an external table, called wdi_csv_text
CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE wdi_csv_text
(year INTEGER, countryName STRING, countryCode STRING, indicatorName STRING, indicatorCode STRING, indicatorValue FLOAT)
ROW FORMAT DELIMITED FIELDS TERMINATED BY ',' LINES TERMINATED BY '\n'
LOCATION 'hdfs:///user/jamesli9572/hive/wdi/wdi_csv_text'

--loads data from wdi_gs table to wdi_csv_text table
INSERT OVERWRITE TABLE wdi_csv_text
SELECT * FROM wdi_gs

--run select statement twice and compare the run time
SELECT count(countryName) FROM wdi_csv_text

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Parsing
The divider for column is simply by a comma. This creates an issue, since the second column may contain comma. As a result, we need to use a smarter SerDe to handle CSV edge cases. The first 3 blocks in this section is usedd to debug the issue, and the rest is used to solve it.

SELECT distinct(indicatorcode)
FROM wdi_csv_text
ORDER BY indicatorcode
LIMIT 20

paragraphs.text:
--#1 create wdi_opencsv_gs and load GS data with OpenCSVSerde
CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE IF NOT EXISTS wdi_opencsv_gs
(year INTEGER, countryName STRING, countryCode STRING, indicatorName STRING, indicatorCode STRING, indicatorValue FLOAT)
ROW FORMAT SERDE 'org.apache.hadoop.hive.serde2.OpenCSVSerde'
WITH SERDEPROPERTIES (
   "separatorChar" = ",",
   "quoteChar"     = "\"",
   "escapeChar"    = "\\"
)
LOCATION 'gs://jarvis_data_eng_james/datasets/wdi_2016'

select distinct(indicatorCode) from wdi_opencsv_gs order by indicatorCode
limit 20

## OpenCSVSerde limitation
SerDe treats all column to be String, even if table have non-String column. We can solve the problem by creating a view over the table that cast the type to user's desired type.

paragraphs.text:
--create a view
CREATE VIEW IF NOT EXISTS wdi_opencsv_text_view AS
SELECT cast(year AS INTEGER), countryname, countrycode, indicatorcode, cast(indicatorvalue AS FLOAT)
FROM wdi_opencsv_text

%md
## 2015 Canada GDP Growth
In this sectin, we will find 2015 GDP growth for canada. The query runs very slow(82s), since the runtimeof the query is O(n). It will need to iterate through all data and return thr required information. We can use partition to slove the problem. The data can be partition by country or year, which will result in less data read and faster.

SELECT distinct(indicatorcode), indicatorname
FROM wdi_opencsv_text
WHERE indicatorcode LIKE '%GDP%'

-- find 2015 Canada GDP
SELECT indicatorvalue, year, countryname
FROM wdi_opencsv_text
WHERE indicatorcode = 'NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG' AND year = '2015' AND countryname = 'Canada'

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Hive Partition
This section solved the issue addressed on the above section. Data will be stored into different file place. In this case, we will partition data by year and compare the performance. The partiton solution takes 2s instead of 88s from the pervious section.

msg.data:
Hive Partition

This section solved the issue addressed on the above section. Data will be stored into different file place. In this case, we will partition data by year and compare the performance.

paragraphs.text:
-- create table which partitioned by year
CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE IF NOT EXISTS wdi_opencsv_text_partitions
(countryName STRING, countryCode STRING, indicatorName STRING, indicatorCode STRING ,indicatorValue FLOAT)
PARTITIONED BY (year INTEGER)
ROW FORMAT DELIMITED
LOCATION 'hdfs:///user/jamesli9572/hive/wdi/wdi_opencsv_text_partitions'

set hive.exec.dynamic.partition.mode=nonstrict 
--set dynamic partition, so we don't have to manage which partition have to be create and inserted into from the input table

--load data
INSERT OVERWRITE TABLE wdi_opencsv_text_partitions PARTITION (year)
SELECT countryname, countrycode, indicatorname, indicatorcode, indicatorvalue, year
FROM wdi_opencsv_text

%sh
# check how many partition created
hdfs dfs -ls hdfs:///user/jamesli9572/hive/wdi/wdi_opencsv_text_partitions

%md
## Columnar File Optimization
A columnar database stores data by columns rather than by rows. Columnar database can efficiently write and read data from hard disk storage in order to speed up the time it takes to return a query. The following section optimize HQL query using columnar method.

msg.data:
Columnar File Optimization

A columnar database stores data by columns rather than by rows. Columnar database can efficiently write and read data from hard disk storage in order to speed up the time it takes to return a query. The following section implement

--create table stored as PARQUET
CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE IF NOT EXISTS wdi_csv_parquet
(year INTEGER, countryName STRING, countryCode STRING, indicatorName STRING, indicatorCode STRING ,indicatorValue FLOAT)
STORED AS PARQUET
LOCATION 'hdfs:///user/jamesli9572/hive/wdi/wdi_csv_parquet'

--load data from wdi_opencsv_gs
INSERT OVERWRITE TABLE wdi_csv_parquet
SELECT * FROM wdi_opencsv_gs

%sh

hdfs dfs -du -s -h hdfs:///user/jamesli9572/hive/wdi/wdi_csv_parquet

%sh
hdfs dfs -du -s -h hdfs:///user/jamesli9572/hive/wdi/wdi_opencsv_text

--compare runtime

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Highest GDP Growth
Since we already optimize the performance using Columnar optimization. Now we will need to do a more complicated query to test the performance. We need to find the highest GDP Growth year for each country. Also execute the same query using SparkSQL.

msg.data:
Highest GDP Growth

Since we already optimize the performance using Columnar optimization. Now we will need to do a more complicated query to test the performance. We need to find the highest GDP Growth year for each country. Also execute the same query using SparkSQL.

paragraphs.text:
-- find highest GDP Growth year for each country
SELECT 
t2.indicatorvalue as GDP_Growth,
t2.year,
t2.countryname as country
FROM (
SELECT max(indicatorvalue) as value, countryname 
FROM wdi_csv_parquet
WHERE indicatorcode = 'NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG' AND indicatorvalue <> 0
GROUP BY countryname 
)t1
inner join wdi_csv_parquet  t2
ON t1.value = t2.indicatorvalue AND t1.countryname = t2.countryname

## Sort GDP
Now we need to display GDP Growth information sorted by country name and year

msg.data:
Sort GDP

Now we need to display GDP Growth information sorted by country name and year

paragraphs.text:
SELECT indicatorvalue as GDP_Growth,
year,
countryname 
FROM
wdi_csv_parquet
WHERE
indicatorcode = 'NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG' 
DISTRIBUTE BY countryname
SORT BY countryname, year
limit 200
